intro: Pterocephalus ghahremanii, commonly known as the Persian ironweed, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Central Asia, particularly Iran and Afghanistan. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble daisies. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments. Its leaves are narrow and hairy, and its flowers are usually purple or pink, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its resilience and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens in regions with similar climates.
